title: Does filing under Chapter 13 eliminate unsecured debt,i.e credit cards,car recpos ?
question: I was told that chapter 13 converts automatically to chapter 7,I am confused because I thought Chaper 13 is to protect secured debt.And if the creditors for the unsecured debt don't show up for the chapter 13 hearings, at that point is the unsecured debt dismissed??
answers: You make a payment based on several factors, usually only pennies on the dollar, and at the end of the bankruptcy (which may take 3-5 years) your debts are elimindated. (ie discharged)

Depends. Dischargeable debts are discharged in a properly filed and completed C13 BK.
C13 does not automatically convert to C&. Only debtor can decide to convert to C7 BK. Debtor also has option to voluntarily dismiss C13 BK.
Proceed very carefully when considering conversion to C7. Debtor has no unilateral right to dismiss a C7 BK.
Question evidences some confusion. Suggest you consult BK counsel before proceeding.

A Chapter 13 does not automatically convert to a Chapter 7. If you are thinking about converting then you should consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney who can properly advise you if converting is in your best interest.

Typically unsecured creditors do not show up at the 341 hearing (the meeting of creditors), however unsecured debt is not discharged until you complete your Chapter 13 plan.

Your question is very confusing. Please call and consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney so you can understand how to move forward in your situation. A Chapter 13 is a reorganization plan where you are paying back some or all of your creditors (depending on how the plan is structured); this can include secured and unsecured debts. A Chapter 7 only eliminates unsecured debts. If you are in a Chapter 13 and cannot afford the "plan payments" then a debtor may elect to convert to a Chapter 7 (if qualifies) to just eliminate unsecured debts.

Chapter 13 cases are not automatically converted to a Chapter 7. The effect of a Chapter 13 discharge can have the same look and feel as a Chapter 7 discharge, however. Everything will hinge on either the completion of your Chapter 13 plan, or the filing the necessary paperwork with the Court to have your case converted to a Chapter 7, and then having the discharge entered. You should seek the advice of local competent attorney who can assist you.

A Chapter 13 case may result in the discharge (elimination) of unsecured debt at the conclusion of the case. (Most cases end in three to five years.)

Chapter 13 does not automatically convert to Chapter 7, although requesting conversion is possible if you can meet the requirements for doing so.

Many people do file Chapter 13 because they want to save assets (house, cars) that have been put up as collateral to secure a debt. Others file because they do not qualify to file a Chapter 7 due to high income.

Creditors are invited to Chapter 13 hearings but are not required to attend and do not lose any rights if they fail to do so. All creditors must file a proof of claim in order to receive payment through the Chapter 13 case. However, failure to file that claim on time does not eliminate the debt. The successful conclusion of the case after three to five years of payments will result in the debtor getting a discharge which is what eliminates the requirement to pay the debts.

It sounds like you've been given some very questionable information - every phrase of your question looks to be the result of receiving incorrect advice. Most bankruptcy attorneys offer free consultations, so do yourself a favor and look through avvo.com's Find a Lawyer tab to find a good, experienced attorney in your area. Chapter 13 is not something you can likely do well on your own (nearly every Chapter 13 case filed by the individual debtor fails).
Based on your question, it is clear that are indeed confused, and need to talk to an experienced bankruptcy attorney who can answer your questions and explain your options.

Although it may be possible to convert from Chapter 13 to Chapter 7, this does not automatically happen. Chapter 13s can be structured in different ways, depending on one's income, assets, debts, etc. In many cases, unsecured debts can be discharged (or wiped out), but you should consult with a competent bankruptcy attorney.
